name: Ferrum phosphoricum
Relationship: Compare: (Oxygenoid Constitution. ACON.; CHINA; ARSENIC; GRAPHIT.; PETROL.) FERRUM PYROPHOSPH. (congestion of brain and headache following great loss of blood; tarsal cysts); ACON.; GELS.; CHINA.
Modalities: Worse: at night and 4 to six am; touch

Eyes: Hyperaemia of optic disc and retina, with blurred vision
Feeling as of sand under lids
Fever: Chill daily at one pm all catarrhal and inflammatory fevers; first stage
Abdomen: First stage of dysentery, with much blood in discharges
Respiratory: Expectoration of pure blood in pneumonia
First stage of all inflammatory affections
Hard, dry cough, with sore chest
Head: Soreness to touch, cold, noise, jar
Vertigo
Throbbing sensation
Headache better cold applications
Rush of blood to head
Ill effects of sun-heat
Face: Facial neuralgia; worse, shaking head and stooping
Throat: After operations on throat and nose to control bleeding and relieve soreness
Subacute laryngitis with fauces inflamed and red
Nose: First stage of colds in the head
Female: Menses every three weeks, with bearing-down sensation and pain on top of head
Extremities: Rheumatic pain in shoulder; pains extend to chest and wrist

details: In the early stages of febrile conditions, it stands midway between sthenic activity of Aconite and Bell, and the asthenic sluggishness and torpidity of GELS. The typical FERR. PHOS. subject is not full blooded and robust, but nervous, sensitive, anaemic with the false plethora and easy flushing of Ferrum. Prostration marked; face more active than GELS. The superficial redness never assumes the dusky hue of GELS. Pulse soft and flowing; no anxious restlessness of ACON. Susceptibility to chest troubles. Bronchitis of young children. In acute exacerbation of tuberculosis, a fine palliative of wonderful power. Corresponds to Grauvogl's Oxygenoid Constitution, the inflammatory, febrile, emaciating, wasting consumption.The remedy for first stage of all febrile disturbances and inflammations before exudation sets in; especially for catarrhal affections of the respiratory tract. FERR. PHOS. 3x increases haemoglobin. In pale, anaemic subjects, with violent local congestions. Hemorrhages, bright from any orifice.
